message_1: How many ways can a committee of 3 people be chosen from a group of 8 if the order in which they are chosen does not matter?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where C(n, k) represents the number of combinations of choosing k items from a set of n items, n! is the factorial of n (the product of all positive integers up to n), and k! is the factorial of k.

In this case, we want to choose a committee of 3 people (k = 3) from a group of 8 people (n = 8). So, we will plug these values into the formula:

C(8, 3) = 8! / (3!(8-3)!)

C(8, 3) = 8! / (3!5!)

Now, we will calculate the factorials:

8! = 8 × 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 40,320
3! = 3 × 2 × 1 = 6
5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 120

Now, we will plug these values back into the formula:

C(8, 3) = 40,320 / (6 × 120)

C(8, 3) = 40,320 / 720

C(8, 3) = 56

So, there are 56 ways to choose a committee of 3 people from a group of 8 if the order in which they are chosen does not matter.
